Index

1/1/2008 GBPG

Posted January 1, 2008

Kabat, Stanley V.

Stanley V. Kabat, 88, Greenleaf, died peacefully Saturday, December 29, 2007 at St. Paul Home in Kaukauna. Stanley was born July 20, 1919 in the town of Wrightstown to Frank & Caroline (Tikalsky) Kabat. He married Florence Nies June 1, 1943, at St. John Catholic Church, Morrison. He was a member of St. Mary Catholic Church, Greenleaf, all his life.

Stanley was a cheese maker and a farmer. He also worked at Brillion Iron Works and retired in 1983. He was a member of St. Mary's Holy Name Society and Catholic Knights Branch 189. His greatest joys were his wife, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

He is survived by his wife, Florence (Nies) and twelve children: Kenneth (Betty) Kabat, Greenleaf; Mary Clare (Gary) Mommaerts, Greenleaf; Cyril (Lois) Kabat, Arlington Heights, IL; Janice (John) Keyzer, Green Bay; Jerome (Marilyn) Kabat, Greenleaf; Luella (Gary) Van Asten, Kaukauna; Catherine (Bob) Janda, Skanee, MI; James (Karen) Kabat, Sussex; Stanley J. (Terri) Kabat , Bettendorf, IA; Roseanne (Tim) Prunty, Antigo; Theresa (Dean) Swoboda, De Pere; Jane (Greg) Kleineschay, De Pere, 29 grandchildren and 18 great-grandchildren.

He is further survived by his sisters: Leona Foytik, Rosella (Joe) Nies; sister-in-law, Ruth Kabat, brother-in-law, Jerry Nies, sister-in-law, Ellen (Glen) Farrell, sister-in-law, Lucy Nies and numerous nieces and nephews.

He was preceded in death by daughters Margaret Ann & her twin sister, a grandson, Tommy Mommaerts, brothers & sisters, Millie & El DeCleene, Father Cyril Kabat, Ceil & Wally Krautkramer, Lan Kabat, Bernadine Nies, sisters and brothers-in-law, Marie (Clarence) Diny, Bill Nies, Bob (Dorothy) Nies, Bernard Nies, Frank Foytik, nieces and nephews, Frank Foytik Jr., Pauline Foytik, Ruth Krautkramer and Howard DeCleene.

Friends may call at Ryan Funeral Home, 305 N. Tenth St., De Pere after 2:00 p.m. on Tuesday, January 1, 2008. Prayer service at 8:00 p.m. to close the evening. Mass of Christian Burial will take place at 10:30 a.m. Wednesday, at St. Mary Catholic Church, Greenleaf with the Reverend Father Bob Kabat and Monsignor John Schuh officiating. There will be no visitation on Wednesday. Please go to www.ryanfh.com to express online condolences to the family.

Stan's family would like to extend a special thanks to the staff of St. Paul Rehabilitation Center, St. Vincent Hospital and Dr. Wampler's Clinic for their tender care of Dad.

Posted January 1, 2008

Reivitis, Tony T.

Tony T. Reivitis, 51, Green Bay passed away on Friday, Dec. 28, 2007 at Aurora hospital with his family by his side. He was born on Aug. 18, 1956 in Lombard, Ill. and was the son of Edmund and Lena (Splingaire) Reivitis. Tony graduated from Green Bay West High School Class of 1974 and furthered his education at UW-Stout with a B.A. Degree in Industrial Arts focusing on Graphic Design. Tony utilized his skills and training while he was employed with 3M Corporation in Graphic Sales. He married Deb Tilot and had three beautiful children, Aaron, Ashley and Lauryn. Tony was a car enthusiast. He enjoyed building dirt track race cars with friends and family in the Seymour area. He was mechanically inclined and eager to help his children and loved ones. Tony was always willing to donate his time, knowledge, and a helping hand to others with projects, small or large. Striking up conversations with total strangers was no problem for him because he enjoyed talking to everyone. Tony enjoyed the simple things in life. His dogs, Thunder and Magnum will miss him dearly.

Tony is survived by his son Aaron (girlfriend Chandra), daughters Ashley and Lauryn, parents Ed and Lena Reivitis, sister Teri Parins, and two brothers, Michael (Kim) Reivitis, Tom (Angie) Reivitis. He is further survived by aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews other relatives and dear friends.

He was preceded in death by his grandparents.

Gathering of family and friends will be held on Wednesday, Jan. 2, 2008 from 3 p.m to 5 p.m. at Saint Bernard's Catholic Church 2040 Hillside Lane, Green Bay. Mass of Christian Burial 5 p.m. at the church with Rev. David Pleier officiating. Burial at Fort Howard Memorial Park.

In lieu of flowers a Memorial Fund has been established in Tony's name. Online condolences may be expressed at www.hansenfuneralservice.com

The family would like to offer a warm note of appreciation to the staff of Aurora VNA Hospice for all of their loving care and attention. Also, a special thank-you to Dr. Dhimant Patel and the entire staff at the Vince Lombardi Cancer Center for their care and compassion.

Hansen Family Funeral

And Cremation Services

1644 Lime Kiln Road

(920) 593-2620

1/1/2008 Post Crescent

Posted January 1, 2008

Anderson, Larry M.

Larry M. Anderson of Neenah passed away peacefully on Friday, December 28, 2007, at the age of 70. Larry lived life the way he wanted to, one day at a time. He will be remembered most for his cantankerous personality and his love of Budweiser.

Survivors include: his children; grandchildren; his ex-wives; his very special friends Mary and Pete; his sister, Lori (Gary) Froehlich, Seymour; sister-in-law and brother-in-law, Bev Anderson, Oneida; Louie Affeldt, Nichols; several aunts, cousins and many nieces and nephews.

Larry was preceded in death by his parents Manuel and Fern Anderson, Nichols; his sister, Sherril Affeldt and his brother, Lee Anderson.

A memorial service will be held at Muehl-Boettcher Funeral Home, Seymour, at 1 p.m. Friday, January 5, 2008, with a gathering from noon until time of services. On line condolences can be made to www.Boettcherfuneralhomes. com

A special thank you to his favorite Uncle Don and special friend Donna for always being there for him when he had to be in Madison at the V.A. for medical issues.

Posted January 1, 2008

Dachelet, Hector T.

Hector T. Dachelet, age 100, of Appleton, died Monday morning, December 31, 2007, on his birthday. He was born December 31, 1907, to the late Henry and Mary (Homblette) Dachelet, in Appleton, where he was a resident most of his life. Hector had been employed by Wisconsin Bell Telephone Company and retired after 43 years of service. He volunteered at the St. Joseph Food Pantry, Salvadorian Brothers, in New London, and numerous church projects. He was a member of St. Joseph Catholic Church and the Telephone Pioneers.

Hector is survived by three children, Thomas C. Dachelet, Squaw Valley, CA; Mary (William) Harris, Belvidere IL; Margaret (Kenneth) Driessen; seven grandchildren, Elizabeth Dachelet, David (Rachael) Hoffman-Dachelet, William (Charleen) Dachelet, Mark (Kimberly) Manthey, Kent (Denise) Manthey, Paul (Kristy) Driessen and Mark (Johanna) Driessen; 15 great-grandchildren.

He was preceded in death by his first wife, Lucille (Roesch) Dachelet, his second wife, Josephine (Foeller) Dachelet, his son, William, three brothers, Henry and two in infancy, two sisters, Alvina Kiel and Emily Wenzel.

The funeral liturgy for Hector will be held at 4 p.m. Thursday, January 3, 2008, at ST. JOSEPH CATHOLIC CHURCH, 410 West Lawrence Street, with Father Larry Abler officiating. Burial will be in St. Mary Cemetery. Friends may call at the church on Thursday from 2 p.m., until the time of the mass. In lieu of flowers a memorial fund is being established for the Theda Clark Neo-Natal Unit.

The family would like to express their gratitude to the staff of Angelus and to Dana and her staff of ThedaCare At Home Hospice.

WICHMANN FUNERAL HOME

537 North Superior Street

Appleton 920-739-1231

www.wichmannfargo.com

1/2/2008 Door County Advocate

Posted December 31, 2007

Kathleen Tlachac

Kathleen Sue (Renk) Tlachac, 61, Forestville passed away at her home Dec. 24, 2007, after a nearly 10-year battle with cancer.

Kathy, formerly of Williamsport, Pa., was born March 5, 1946.

Kathy met her husband, Marty, while he served in the U.S. Air Force. They later married on Aug. 16, 1969.

Before settling in Forestville, Kathy and Marty joined the Peace Corps and served in the country of Honduras from 1971 to 1973. As of late, she was employed as a secretary at Family Worship Center Ministries in Sturgeon Bay.

Survivors include her husband, Marty; a daughter, Angela, Denver, Colo.; a son and daughter-in-law, Matthew and Heidi, London, Ohio; two sisters and two brothers, Carol Ann Johnson, Montoursville, Pa., Rosie Ramirez, Laredo, Texas, Charles Renk and Daniel Renk, Williamsport, Pa.; mother-in-law, Helen (Holsbach) Tlachac; sisters and brothers-in-law, Sylvia (Richard) Corbeill, New Franken, Claire (Larry) Peters, Bellevue, Barbara Settles, Seoul, South Korea, Cindy (Jack) Nisbet, Tuscon, Ariz., Greg (Stephanie) Tlachac, Salt Lake City, Utah, Randy (Carol) Tlachac, Plymouth, Minn., and Kristine (Gregory) Nebel, Merton, Wis.; numerous nieces and nephews, and many dearly loved friends.

She was preceded in death by her parents, Charles and June Renk; father-in-law, Vojta Tlachac; nephew, Gregory Corbeill; nieces, Stephanie Corbeill and Faith Peters.

Memorial services will be 10:30 a.m. Saturday, Dec. 29, at Family Worship Center, Sturgeon Bay, the Rev. Dr. Mark Schwarzbauer officiating. Visitation will be 4 to 8 p.m. Friday at Forbes Funeral Home and then after 9:30 a.m. Saturday at Family Worship Center until time of services. A devotion will be conducted on Friday at the funeral home at 7:30 p.m.

Memorials may be directed to Door CANcer in her name. Online condolences may be offered from www.forbesfuneralhome. com

1/2/2008 Post Crescent

Posted January 2, 2008

Huss, Jane R.

Jane R. Huss, 44, Kaukauna, passed away peacefully at St. Elizabeth's Hospital surrounded by her family and friends on Dec. 29, 2007. She was born on Sept. 3, 1963, to Clifford Huss and Ruth (Wyngaard) Huss in Kaukauna. Jane enjoyed shooting darts and playing cards, camping, spending time up north with friends and babysitting for one and all.

Jane is survived by her parents and siblings, Mary, Linda, Sue (Larry) Duda, Wayne (Chris), all of Kaukauna; Betty, Appleton; Nancy, Neenah; Paul (Linda), Fremont; Karen (Charles) Harp Jr., New London; and Amy Sue, Little Chute; nieces and nephews, Becky, Tina, Chris Jr., Travis, Jim, Tom, Cliff, Stephanie, Barbara, Melody, Charlie, Jessica, Tyler, Heather, Katrina; and eight great-nieces and great-nephews. She is also survived by her special friend, Jim VandenBosch and his three children, Emily, Amber and Ashley; and dear friends, Jan (Randy) VanAsten, Terri (Squeak) and Jason Braeger and their two daughters Brianna and Marissa.

She was preceded in death by her son, Dennis James; a sister, Donna; a nephew, Lee Charles Harp; two stepmothers, Elaine Fleischman and Elaine Grawitch; and special friend, Linda Miller.

Jane's memorial service will be at 6 p.m. on Monday, Jan. 7, 2008, at the Boettcher Family Funeral Home, 2401 Fieldcrest Drive, Kaukauna. Friends will be received at the funeral home on Monday from 3 p.m. until the time of service.

In lieu of flowers, a memorial is being established in Jane's name.

The Boettcher Family Funeral Home, Kaukauna, is assisting the family. 920-766-2099 .

The family would like to thank the ICU staff and Jan for the special attention they showed our sister during her final days.

We are at peace knowing your pain and suffering has subsided. The love, joy and happiness that you have given us will forever remain in our hearts.

Posted January 2, 2008

Stadler, Chase Marvin

Chase Marvin Stadler, age 2, of Neenah, passed away peacefully at home on Saturday, December 29, 2007, surrounded by his family. He was born in Appleton on September 16, 2005, to Jaime L. Page-Stadler and Joel Stadler.

Survivors include his parents Jaime and Joel, Neenah; his sister Emily, Neenah; grandparents: Robert and Cheryl Page, Neenah; grandmother Charlotte Belonger, Appleton; aunt and uncle Mike and Heidi Wudi, Appleton; uncle Robert Page, Appleton; and niece and nephew Emma and Samuel Wudi, Appleton. Chase is further survived by nine very special nurses that became an integral part of our family. They provided Chase with exceptional medical care, compassion and comfort. He was truly blessed to have them in his life. They include: Tracy Adams, Julie Dubois, Renee Holdren, Michelle Jahnke, Elaine Laczny, Anne Muza, Wendy Sellier, Nicole Stephani and Teri Werner.

Chase was preceded in death by his paternal grandfather, Marvin Stadler.

Funeral services will be held at 11:00 a.m. on Friday, January 4, 2008, at Faith Lutheran Church, 601 E. Glendale Ave., Appleton, 54911, with Pastor John Scott officiating. Visitation will be from 9:00 a.m. until time of service at the church on Friday and on Thursday, January 3, 2008, from 5 to 7 p.m. at Valley Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, a memorial fund is being established.

The family would like to thank a number of medical professionals for all their efforts in caring for Chase including: Pediatrician Dr. William Kasper; Neonatologist Dr Kimberly Seeger; Neurologist Dr. Terrence Edgar; the 9 wonderful nurses that cared for Chase at home, the nurses in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit at St. Elizabeth Hospital and numerous others that have cared for Chase during his short life. Finally, to all of our family and friends, we appreciate all of your prayers.

To Our Son:

Words can't express how much we love you. You were given to us as a true gift from God. You brought a new perspective to our lives when you were born. We learned what it means to be a parent and how to love one another unconditionally. Until we're reunited in Heaven, we'll cherish the memories of how your smiles and dimples expressed your love for us and warmed our hearts. We love you little buddy!

Love Mom, Dad and Emily!

Valley Funeral Home

2211 N. Richmond St.

Appleton, WI 54911

1/2/2008 Oconto County Reporter

Mr. Arthur L. LeMay

Mr. Arthur L. LeMay, 92, Oconto, died Saturday evening, December 15, 2007 at Woodlands of Oconto.

Mr. LeMay was born Arthur Louis LeMay, April 9, 1915 in Oconto, to Thomas and Mayme (Chezek) LeMay. He married Carol Funk, January 27, 1920. Art was a veteran of World War II. Art operated his own plumbing and heating business and retired in 1977.

He was a member of Holy Trinity Parish, Oconto. Art enjoyed fishing, gardening, music and reading.

Surviving are children, Clarice Bolitho and her husband, Richard, Oconto, Richard LeMay and special friend, Rosemary Metzler, Oconto, Sharon Roulette and her husband, Robert, Stiles, Julie Dorsey, Kent, Washington; sisters, Mrs. Adelaide Karbon and Mrs. Maryrose Frewerd, Oconto; nine grandchildren and twelve great-grandchildren.

Preceding Art in death were his wife Carol in 1998, his parents, two children, Carolyn and Louis, a sister, Blanche Foelker, brothers, Thomas and Harold "Mike", two grandsons, Kevin Roulette and Michael LeMay and a special friend, Doris Schmidt.

The family received relatives and friends at Holy Trinity Catholic Church, Oconto, from 9:00 until 10:45 a.m. Thursday, December 20, 2007. Funeral Mass was 11:00 a.m. Thursday, in the Church with the Rev. Father Patrick Beno officiating. Military rites by Jones-Modrow-Young American Legion Post 74 and burial followed at Oconto Catholic Cemetery.

The family would like to thank Dr. S. Kumar for his wonderful care provided over the years. Also to Woodlands of Oconto, especially Shirley and Angela and Heartland Hospice for their great care as well.

Ackerman Funeral Directors, Oconto, cared for the arrangements.

1/3/2008 GBPG

Posted January 3, 2008

Hagemeier, Harlan D. "Huck"

Harlan D. "Huck" Hagemeier, 77, Green Bay, died peacefully at St. Vincent Hospital on Dec. 30, 2007.

He was born Oct. 3, 1930, in Decorah, Iowa, to Albert and Olga (Halversen) Hagemeier.

After high school graduation, Huck enlisted in the Navy, serving his country in the Bikini Atoll during early atomic bomb experiments. He also toured the Polar Ice Cap and Korea during his Navy days.

On June 28, 1952, he was united in marriage to his high school sweetheart, Rose Pisney, at St. Stephen Catholic Church in Chester, Iowa.

Huck and Rose made their home and proudly raised their three daughters, Patricia, Terry and Lisa, in Austin, Minn., after his honorable discharge from the Navy.

Huck resumed his career as a truck driver, working for Armstrong Truck Lines. In 1966, the Hagemeier family moved to Green Bay, where Huck worked for Packerland Packing Company, a career that lasted 30 years. Along with his wife, he owned R&H Trucking Company for 10 years. During the 1970s and 80s, Huck enjoyed many hours watching Terry and Lisa compete with the family's quarter horses. He created a horse trailer and changing room for the girls from an old school bus and their presence at horse shows was hard to miss.

Huck enjoyed cheering for (and sometimes yelling at) the Green Bay Packers, NASCAR (he once watched the Talladega race atop a semi truck parked outside turn 4 of the track), fishing in Door County and Canada and scooting around the Oneida casino in his wheelchair.

His surviving family includes his loving wife of 55 years, Rose; his beloved daughters, Patricia Hendricks (and his still special ex-son-in law Randy Hendricks), Dubuque, Iowa; Terry Hagemeier (and special friend Laurie Cooney), Oneida, Wis.; and Lisa Madsen (and his loyal fishing buddy and son-in-law Larry Madsen), Sturgeon Bay, Wis. A grandson, Christian Hendricks, Sioux Falls, S.D., and granddaughter, Allison Hendricks, Dubuque, Iowa, held special places in his heart along with his newest delight, his great-granddaughter, Kaitlyn. His Jack Russell Terriers, Cleo and Jake, brought him great joy and constant companionship.

Harlan was preceded in death by his parents and his only brother, Albert Lee Hagemeier.

His eyes and tissue will live on through his generous donations to others.

Memorial services will be held on Friday, Jan. 4, 2008, at Saint Bernard's Church, 2040 Hillside Lane Green Bay, with a friends and family gathering starting at 9 a.m. and Mass at 11 a.m.

Because his wife and daughters made sure that Harlan had lots of flowers during his lifetime, they now respectfully request that you give memorials, instead of flowers, to St. Bernard/St. Philip Catholic Churches of Green Bay.

Toodaaalooo Buckaroo..

Never say goodbye, say See ya..

Posted January 3, 2008

Peters, Mary A.

Mary A. Peters, 84, Green Bay resident, died Sunday, Dec. 30, 2007, at a local nursing home.

She was born Oct.14, 1923, in Green Bay, to the late William and Arlene (Radue) Proctor.

Mary wed Raphael Peters on Oct. 11, 1947, at St. Willebrords Catholic Church. He preceded her in death Nov. 17, 1991.

She bowled on a league for over 30 years and enjoyed playing cards. Mary was a member of St. Agnes Parish.

She is survived by three sons and daughters-in-law, Steve (Judy) Peters, Green Bay; John (Lynn) Peters, New London; Larry (Catherine) Peters, Green Bay; three grandsons, Matthew (Bridget), Steven R. (fiancee, Melissa Chavas), David A. Peters; one sister, Cecelia Lucas, Milwaukee; two sisters-in-law, Dorothy Van Sistine, Appleton; and Theresa Otis, De Pere; nieces and nephews.

She was preceded in death by two sisters, Betty Clumb and Shirley Putnam.

Friends may call at the Proko-Wall Funeral Home, 1630 E. Mason St., after 10 a.m. Friday until time of service. Memorial service noon on Friday with Deacon Jim Gauthier officiating. Burial to follow in Allouez Cemetery. Online condolences may be sent to the Peters family at www.prokowall.com.

Posted January 3, 2008

Sterletske, Raymond J.

Raymond J. Sterletske, 69, the Wisconsin Veterans Home at King and a former Manitowoc County resident died peacefully on Tuesday afternoon, Jan. 1, 2008, at the Appleton Medical Center, surrounded by his family.

Raymond was born Oct. 4, 1938, in the town of New Denmark, Brown County, son of the late Peter and Katherine Wozniak Sterletske.

He was a graduate of Denmark High School. Raymond was a United States Army Veteran serving from 1958 to 1960. On April 14, 1962, Raymond was married to the former Oramae Reedy at St. Joseph Catholic Church in Kellnersville. He worked as finance and insurance representative most of his life. Raymond was a member of Holy Family Parish in Brillion and the Reedsville Amvets Post 1032. He was a life-long Green Bay Packer fan and never missed a game.

Survivors include his loving wife of 45 years, Oramae Sterletske, King; three sons and two daughters-in-law, Bill (Nancy) Sterletske, De Pere; Ted (Robin) Sterletske, Brillion; Chuck Sterletske, Whitelaw and his special friend, Michelle Richardson; seven grandchildren, Michael (Jennifer) Kaufmann, Casey Kaufmann (currently serving in U.S. Army in Afghanistan), Nicole Sterletske, Katie Sterletske, Amanda Sterletske, Jennifer Sterletske, and Ryan Sterletske; two great-grandchildren, Travis and Carter Kaufmann; two sisters, Marie Sterletske, Denmark; Isabel Sterletske, Denmark; one brother, Theodore Sterletske, Denmark; two sisters-in-law and two brothers-in-law, Betty (Roy) Hoffman, Whitelaw; Julianne (Tom) Umentum, Waupun; nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends survive.

He was preceded in death by his parents, Peter and Katherine Sterletske; one sister, Alice Sterletske; one sister-in-law, Mary Sterletske; his father-in-law and mother-in-law, Norbert and Arleen Reedy.

Funeral services will be held at 10:30 a.m. on Friday, Jan. 4, 2008, at Holy Family Parish in Brillion. The Rev. Matthew Simonar will celebrate the Mass of Christian Burial with burial to follow at Holy Trinity Cemetery at Pine Grove. Relatives and friends may call at the Reinbold & Pfeffer Family Funeral Home of Kellnersville on Thursday (TODAY) from 4 p.m. until 8 p.m. and on Friday at the church from 9:30 a.m. until the time of services at 10:30 a.m. There will be a parish wake service at the funeral home on Thursday (TONIGHT) at 7:30 p.m. led by Deacon Steve Letourneaux

Posted January 3, 2008

Vandehei, William "Bill" J.

William "Bill" J. Vandehei, 71, Oneida, died Tuesday, Jan. 1, 2008, at home with his family by his side.

Bill was born in De Pere, Dec. 16, 1936, a son of the late Frank and Josephine (Vercauteren) Vandehei. He was a graduate of West High School in 1955. Bill entered the Marines in 1955 serving two years. He married Alice Aerts Oct. 4, 1958. He then married Carol Coopman Feb. 9, 1963.

Bill ran the family farm in Oneida for years. Then he owned Vandehei Repairs and sold Snap-On Tools. Finally he went into real estate and started Vandehei Improvements and built many beautiful cabinets and etc. He was inducted into the Bowling Hall of Fame Nov. 5, 1988. His true love was camping and fishing with family and friends.

Bill will be sadly missed by his wife, Carol; sons, Jay and David (special friend, Brenda); daughter, Roxann (Mark) Youngs; grandchildren, Hayley Youngs, Nicholas and Phillip Vandehei, and Candice Vandehei; great-grandchildren, Haiden Vandehei and Brooklyn Vandehei. He is further survived by his sisters, Rosemary (Ted) Prosser, Alyce (Jerry) Berken, Anita (Michael) Perock, and Faye (Reuel) Robertson; brother, Vernon (Violet); sisters-in-law, Jean and Delores Vandehei; brothers-in-law, Gary (Carol) Coopman and Dan (Barbara) Coopman; sister-in-law, Helen Lemmen; and many nieces, nephews, and other relatives and friends.

He was preceded in death by his parents, Frank and Josephine Vandehei; sisters, Helen Lemmen and Jeanette Puyleart; brothers, Jim and Richard Vandehei; and his first wife, Alice Vandehei.

Visitation for Bill will be Friday, Jan. 4, 2008, at RYAN FUNERAL HOME, 305 N. Tenth St. from 4 to 8 p.m. with a Prayer service at 8 p.m. Visitation will continue on Saturday, Jan. 5, 2008, at St. Joseph Catholic Church - Oneida from 9:30 a.m. to time of Mass. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 10:30 a.m. with Fr. David Koch officiating. Military Rites to follow at church. Entombment to be held at Shrine of the Good Shepherd. Please visit www.ryanfh.com to send online condolences to the Vandehei family.

The family would like to thank the Aurora VNA staff and all friends and family for support during this time.

1/3/2008 Post Crescent

Posted January 3, 2008

Vander Bloomen, Frederick L.

Frederick L. Vander Bloomen, Kaukauna, age 78, passed away peacefully at Appleton Medical Center on Tuesday, January 1, 2008. He was born in Kaukauna on April 7, 1929, the son of the late Frederick and Louise (Vanden Bloomer) Vander Bloomen. Fred was proud to serve in the United States Navy in 1946 and served on the U.S.S. Kersarge. He married his wife of 56 years, Jean Servaes in Kaukauna on October 20, 1951.

Fred worked for the Kaukauna Electric and Water Department (Kaukauna Utilities) and was a member of Holy Cross Catholic Church, Kaukauna. Fred enjoyed playing the keyboard, the accordion, and going to the casino. He also enjoyed gardening and raising animals. His family was very important to him, including spending time with his grandchildren. He will be remembered for his love of Honda Goldwings with side cars, being a "jack of all trades," and being a jokester.

Fred is survived by his wife, Jean, children: Dale Vander Bloomen, Kaukauna; Lori (Greg) Welhouse, Kaukauna; grandchildren: Mindy and Tracy Vander Bloomen and Alicia Welhouse, Kaukauna; sisters: Alma (Tony) Gazzanna, West Allis; Lucille Hopfensperger, Eugene, Oregon; Jane (Emil) St. John, Kaukauna; and Joan (Joseph) Lewandowski, Kimberly; and daughter-in-law, Sue Allgeyer, Kaukauna.

He is preceded in death by his son, James Vander Bloomen on November 13, 1996; brothers and sisters: Floyd and Richie Vander Bloomen, Alice (Bob) Nack, Carol (Lawrence) Van Cuyk, and Gerald (Marie) Vanden Bloomen.

The funeral service will be at 12 p.m. on Saturday, January 5, 2008, at the Fargo Funeral Home, with Fr. Tom Pomeroy officiating. Friends will be received at the funeral home on Saturday from 9 a.m. until the time of the service. Burial will be in Trinity Lutheran Cemetery, Kaukauna.

The family extends a special thank you to Dr. Wolfmeyer (retired), Dr. Gustafson, Dr. Danz, Dr. Russo and the staff at Kaukauna Clinic for their care and concern for Fred over so many years.

"I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith. Henceforth there is laid up for me the crown of righteousness."

II Timothy 4:7-8

Beloved husband, brother, father and grandpa, thank you for the many lessons, laughs and memories. You will be forever in our hearts. May God keep you in his loving care until we may all be together again in His Kingdom.

Forever and always in my heart, Jean.

FARGO FUNERAL HOME

400 West Wisconsin Avenue

Kaukauna

1/4/2008 GBPG

Posted January 4, 2008

Coppens, Jeremiah Daniel

Jeremiah Daniel Coppens, 22, Fairview Heights, Ill., formerly of Green Bay, entered into eternal peace Monday, Dec. 31, 2007.

He was born Dec. 23, 1985, in Green Bay, to Amanda (Kramer) Bowser and Daniel Coppens.

Jeremiah recently graduated from Belleville East High School in Fairview Heights, Ill., and attended Southwestern Illinois University. He had enjoyed many years of camp and made many friendships while attending MDA Summer Camp.

Jeremiah had been living with his precious Aunt Tina, Uncle Tony, and wonderful cousins, Matthew, Steven, Nicholas, Robert and Tawnee. Jeremiah was an avid wrestling fan and a die-hard Oakland Raiders fan. He had a wonderful sense of humor and especially enjoyed the times spent with family and friends.

He is survived by his parents, Amanda Bowser and her significant other, Keith Halonen, Green Bay; Daniel Coppens, Abrams; his grandparents, Robert and Viola Schoen, Green Bay; Mary Paye, Abrams; three brothers and one sister, Holly, Christopher, Andrew, Daniel; his aunts and uncles, Kim Hecker, Tina Kramer and Tony Hammonds, Ronica Kramer, Kellie and Dave Langer, Dave, Todd and Shannon Kramer, Jeff and Tammy Schoen, Brian Schoen; his cousins, Tad, Adam, Kayla, Toni, Samantha, Amy, Todd, Ari, Katrina, Grant, Dagan; a very special friend, Carolynne Younk, MDA Director; many other relatives and friends.

He was preceded in death by his grandfather, Robert Kramer; and his grandparents, Raymond and Veronica Kramer.

Friends may call at St. Joseph Catholic Church, corner of Ninth St. and 12th Ave., from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. Saturday. The Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 1 p.m. Saturday at the church with the Rev. Andrew Kysely officiating. Burial will be in Allouez Catholic Cemetery.

A very special thank you to all of the counselors and friends Jeremiah made while attending MDA Camp.

Blaney Funeral Home is assisting the family. To send online condolences, please go to www.BlaneyFuneralHome.com.

Posted January 4, 2008

Dantoin, Donald "Don"

Donald "Don" Dantoin, 71, Green Bay, passed away Thursday, Jan. 3, 2008, at a local nursing home. Arrangements will be announced by RYAN FUNERAL HOME.

Posted January 4, 2008

Thiry, Bart G.

Mr. Bart Gerard Thiry, 35, Rosiere, died unexpectedly Wednesday, Jan. 2, 2008.

He was born in Green Bay March 4, 1972, to Dale H. and Rachel A. (Rubens) Thiry. Bart graduated from Luxemburg-Casco High School Class of 1990.

Posted January 4, 2008

Harlan Hagemeier

Harlan D. Huck Hagemeier, 77, Green Bay, died peacefully Sunday, Dec. 30, 2007, at St. Vincent Hospital.

He was born Oct. 3, 1930, in Decorah, Iowa, to Albert and Olga (Halversen) Hagemeier.

After high school graduation, Huck enlisted in the Navy, serving his country in the Bikini Atoll during early atomic bomb experiments. He also toured the polar ice cap and Korea during his Navy days.

June 28, 1952, he was united in marriage to his high school sweetheart, Rose Pisney, at St. Stephen Catholic Church in Chester, Iowa.

Huck and Rose made their home and proudly raised their three daughters, Patricia, Terry and Lisa, in Austin, Minn., after his honorable discharge from the Navy.

Huck resumed his career as a truck driver, working for Armstrong Truck Lines. In 1966, the Hagemeier family moved to Green Bay, where Huck worked for Packerland Packing Company, a career that lasted 30 years. Along with his wife, he owned R&H Trucking Company for 10 years.

During the 1970s and 80s, Huck enjoyed many hours watching Terry and Lisa compete with the familys quarter horses. He created a horse trailer and changing room for the girls from an old school bus and their presence at horse shows was hard to miss.

Huck enjoyed cheering for (and sometimes yelling at) the Green Bay Packers, NASCAR (he once watched the Talladega race atop a semi truck parked outside turn four of the track), fishing in Door County and Canada, and scooting around the Oneida Casino in his wheelchair.

His surviving family includes his loving wife of 55 years, Rose; his beloved daughters, Patricia Hendricks (and his still special ex-son-in-law, Randy Hendricks) Dubuque, Iowa, Terry Hagemeier (and special friend Laurie Cooney), Oneida, and Lisa Madsen (and his loyal fishing buddy and son-in-law Larry Madsen) Sturgeon Bay. A grandson, Christian Hendricks, Sioux Falls, S.D., and granddaughter, Allison Hendricks, Dubuque, Iowa, held special places in his heart, along with his newest delight, his great-granddaughter, Kaitlyn. His Jack Russell terriers, Cleo and Jake, brought him great joy and constant companionship.

Harlan was preceded in death by his parents and his only brother, Albert Lee Hagemeier.

His eyes and tissue will live on through his generous donations to others.

Memorial services were held Friday, Jan. 4, at St. Bernard's Church, Green Bay, with a friends and family gathering that started at 9 a.m. and Mass at 11 a.m.

Because his wife and daughters made sure that Harlan had lots of flowers during his lifetime, they now respectfully request that you give memorials, instead of flowers, to St. Bernard/St. Phillip Catholic churches of Green Bay.

James E. Renier

James E. Renier, 81, Denmark, died peacefully Friday, Jan. 4, 2008, at Unity Hospice. He was born on Jan. 3, 1927, the son of the late Alex and Clara (Des Jardin) Renier. He graduated from East High School in Green Bay in 1945. He married the former Regina Lancelle on May 18, 1946. He served in the U.S. Army from 1945 to 1947.

Upon his discharge from the service, he earned his Bachelor of Science degree from St. Norbert College, and his Master of Science degree in Education from the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

He dedicated his entire 38-year career to the students of the Denmark School District, holding a variety of positions including elementary school teacher at Bungalow School, bus driver, librarian, math teacher, English teacher, and assistant football coach. He served as principal for 20 years and superintendent for seven. Jim enjoyed daily interaction with students, and took immense pride in the achievements of several generations of Denmark Vikings.

"J.R." was always active in the community. He was a 50-year member of the American Legion, serving as commander and finance officer. He was a lifetime member of the Denmark FF Alumni. He also served on the Denmark State Bank Board of Directors from 1989 to 2006.

He was an avid sportsman, enjoying hunting, fishing, snowmobiling, camping, gardening, and especially time spent at his "hideway" in Amberg.

Jim is survived by his wife of 61 years, Regina; five children: Barbara (Rob) Robinson, Oconto; James Jr. (Ginger) Renier, Denmark; Jeanne (Carter) Hendricksen, Oshkosh; Jeffrey (Nancy) Renier, Madison; and Rachal Van Den Elzen, Appleton; 10 grandchildren: Lisa (Renier) Thomas, Benjamin Renier, Timothy Renier, Courtney Hendricksen, Jamie Renier, Christina Hendricksen, Alex Renier, Corey Renier, Gabriella Van Den Elzen, and Sophia Van Den Elzen; two great-grandchildren: Darian Renier and Genevieve Thomas; and two sisters-in-law, Laurine Lancelle and Marie Renier.

He was also preceded in death by a sister, June Renier; three brothers, Roger Renier, Marvin Renier, and Donald Renier; and brothers-in-law and sisters in law: O.J. Lancelle, and Mary Ann and Jack Webb.

Friends may call at Knutson-Cotter Funeral Home, 536 County Road R, Denmark, on Sunday, Jan. 6, 2008, from 3 until 8 p.m. The American Legion will conduct a service at 6:30 p.m., and there will be a parish prayer service at 7 p.m. Visitation will continue at Knutson-Cotter Funeral Home on Monday, Jan. 9, from 9:30 a.m. until the procession leaves for All Saints Catholic Church where the Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10:30 a.m. with Father Ron Colombo officiating. Interment with full military honors will follow at All Saints Cemetery.

Jim's family would like to extend their sincerest gratitude to Father Ron Colombo, Drs. Posted January 8, 2008

Berendsen, Don

Don Berendsen, 71, Howard, died Thursday Jan. 3, 2008, in Florida after a long, courageous battle with complications of esophageal cancer.

Don (Mr. "B") was called by the Lord to join his heavenly family and friends.

Don graduated in 1954 from Central Catholic High School. He was an alumnus of Wisconsin State University-Whitewater and earned a master's degree from Western State University, Gunnison, Colorado, in 1966.

Mr. "B" was a respected name given Don by students and remained with him for the 35 years he taught high school business. Don began his teaching career at Wabeno in 1959, moved to Preble High School in 1962 and continued his teaching career at Ashwaubenon High School from 1966 to 1994. Students admired Don for his knowledge, enthusiasm, and compassion often honoring him by choosing him as Class Teacher of the Year.

After educational retirement, Don became a "multi-million dollar" real-estate producer for ERA Titletown Realtors and devoted more time to volunteer work at the homeless shelter, the Green Bay Correctional Facility, The Salvation Army and his parish.

Capitalizing on his organization abilities, Don was instrumental in establishing, maintaining and directing the Woodfield Village Homeownwers'Association. He served as WVHA president for many years.

Don enjoyed cooking for family and friends. His interest in food preparation began in 1951 when he became chef at the Zuider Zee Supper Club at the age of 15. He was a partner in the Ye Olde Chatterhouse in De Pere and went on to become the Owner of the Golden Iris Supper Club and Mr. B's Pizza station on Bay Settlement Rd.

One of Don's interests was collecting, showing and preserving old and/or antique automobiles. As a member of the Nickel A Region Model A Club, Don was the chairperson/organizer of four "GB Auto Shows and Swap Meets" at Lambeau Field in the 70s.

In 1983, Don was awarded a "plaque of appreciation" for his efforts in founding, organizing and directing the Howard-Suamico Youth Soccer Association. He enjoyed traveling, cruising, playing cards, watching spectator sports and playing with his family dogs, Chloe, Marty and Abby.

Survivors include his wife, Donna (Ploederl); three daughters, Laura and son-in-law, Rene Cortez; Amy and Melinda; two sons, Mark; James and daughter-in-law, Kim, five grandchildren, Carlos, Santiago, Antonio, Maya and Carolina; a sister and brother-in-law, Marilyn and Paul Stodola, Florida.

He was preceded in death by his son, Edward "Eddie" Berensden; his mother, Luella; his father, Donald; his stepfather, George White; his sister and brother-in-law, Barbara and Dick Joski.

David Kasperek officiating.

Lois was baptized Sept. 7, 1919, and confirmed May 29, 1932 at St. Paul's Lutheran Church, Algoma.

She attended the Victory School in Forestville and graduated from the Algoma High School. She then graduated from the Manitowoc Business College.

Lois married Don Rogers at St. Paul's Church on Sept. 16, 1961. Lois worked as an administrative assistant for the Milwaukee County School of Nursing.

She is survived by one sister-in-law, Norma Mueller, Algoma; nephews and nieces, Janet Mueller, Wisconsin Rapids, Wis.; Robert (Sharon) Mueller, Dubuque, Iowa; Marilyn (William) Anzur, Beaverton, Ore.; Kathleen (Dean) Collins, Black River Falls, Wis.; Larry (Kathleen) Mueller, Arlington, Texas; Mary (Steve) Curtin, Appleton, Wis.; Arnold (Janice) Mueller, Algoma, Wis.; Sharon Mueller, Algoma, Wis.; and Donald Mueller, Milwaukee, Wis.

She was preceded in death by her parents, five brothers, three sisters and two nephews, Eugene and Darold Mueller.

Friends may call at the Schinderle Funeral Home, Algoma, from 2 p.m. Wednesday, Jan. 9, 2008, until time of services at 3:30 p.m. with Rev. John Neugebauer officiating. Burial in the Evergreen Cemetery, Algoma.

Online condolences may be express at www.schinderle.com.

Posted January 8, 2008

Sahaida, Berniece M. "Bunnie"

Berniece M. "Bunnie" Sahaida, 83, De Pere, passed away peacefully, Monday, Jan. 7, 2008.

She is the daughter of the late Henry and Tillie (Gougeon) Simard, born on Jan. 29, 1924, in Chassell, Mich.

They moved from the family farm to Green Bay when she was about 7 years old.

Berniece married her high school sweetheart, Michael Sahaida, on July 1, 1943.

She traveled to wherever Mike came into port while he was in the service, just so they could be together.

Berniece was very devoted to her entire family, putting all her heart and soul into making a loving home and life for her family. She liked to do the newest craft of the year, especially drying flowers. Berniece had a special passion for genealogy, not only contributing to the Simard genealogy but also endless hours researching the Rouse family tree.

Berniece and Mike loved the outdoors, they enjoyed camping trips with their family and friends. Mike taught her how to fish and in later years she was his fishing companion in Canada. She loved to feed the birds and nurture them through the winter. She enjoyed golfing, cards and snowmobiling up at the cottage.

She was a member of St. Francis Xavier Parish in De Pere, where she was an altar society member. For many years she volunteered at St. Francis Grade School. She was proud of her friends and played bridge with the same group of ladies for over 40 years.

Survivors include her daughter, Julie (Jeff/ known as Jake by Mom) Jaco, De Pere; sons, Jeffrey, Green Bay and Jerome, Horicon; four grandchildren, Jocelyn Blazek, Aleea Drewiske, Henry (Hank) Drewiske, Alexis Sahaida; two sisters, Pearl Barrette, Green Bay; Shirley (Bob) Giftt, Hopkins, Minn.; one brother, Harry Simard, Tipler, Wis.; one brother-in-law, Robert Hollister, Green Bay; many nieces and nephews.

She was preceded in death by her husband, Mike, on April 12, 2001; sisters, Leah, Yvonne, Doris, Beatrice, Eleanor; brother, Chester.

Family and friends may call at Cotter Funeral Home, 860 N. Webster Ave., De Pere, on Wednesday, Jan. 9, 2008, from 4 to 8 p.m. A parish wake service will be held at 7:30 p.m. Visitation will continue on Thursday, Jan. 10, 2008, at St. Francis Xavier Parish, 220 S. Michigan St., De Pere, from 10 to 11 a.m. A Mass of Christian Burial will be at 11 a.m. with the Rev. David Duffeck officiating. Interment at Mt. Olivet Cemetery. Online condolences may be expressed to the family at cotterfuneralhome.com.

A special thank you to Dee Ellefson and the staff of Birch Creek, as well as Mary Ahrndt and Heartland Hospice for making Mom's last days special.

Tlachac, Robert (Bob)

Robert (Bob) Tlachac, 83, Forestville, passed away Saturday, Jan. 5, 2008, at Algoma Long Term Care Unit.

He was born Sept. 26, 1924, in the town of Brussels, to the late Walter and Lucy (Kinnard) Tlachac.

He married Grace Dantoin June 27, 1950, at St. Hubert Catholic Church, Rosiere.

Bob farmed his entire lifetime in the town of Brussels until his retirement when he moved to Forestville 10 years ago.

He graduated from Lincoln Graded School and attended Algoma High School. He enjoyed playing cards, watching the Packers, fishing and having company over. He was a member of Catholic Order of Foresters, Knights of Columbus and St. Hubert Holy Name Society.

Bob is survived by his wife, Grace; his daughter, Becky Stewart, Phoenix, Ariz.; his son, Michael Tlachac, Forestville; a grandson, Tyler Stewart, Phoenix, Ariz.; two sisters-in-law, Otilla Wautlet, Casco; and Esther Burke, Kewaunee; an aunt, Rita (Earl) Arbter, Florida; nieces and nephews.

He was preceded in death by a son, Paul.

Funeral 11 a.m. Wednesday at St. Hubert Catholic Church, Rosiere with Fr. Bob Konkol, OFM, officiating and Fr. Dennis Drury concelebrating. Burial in the church cemetery.

Posted January 8, 2008

Smith, Carmen R.

Carmen R. (Phillips) Smith, age 75, of Appleton, passed away on Sunday, January 6, 2008, at Cherry Meadows Hospice after losing her battle with cancer. She was born on August 23, 1932 in Bear Creek, daughter of the late, Harvey and Iva (Malliet) Phillips. Carmen married Harold Smith on July 27, 1949 at St. Mary Catholic Church, Bear Creek. She and Harold lived and farmed in the Bear Creek area and also owned and operated Harold's Welcome Inn in Bear Creek. Carmen moved to Appleton after Harold died in 1994. There she met and married Carlos Yowell on October 24, 2001, who has been the love of her life ever since. Carmen loved to travel. Together with Harold they visited 48 states in their motor home. She toured Europe twice. Then with Carlos, they visited the last two states of Hawaii and Alaska plus many more journeys throughout this country and Mexico. Some of their favorite places were Las Vegas and Branson, MO. With her best friend Kit, she would go anywhere and everywhere to feel the adventure of new places. Carmen also loved to tell stories of her many adventures and she never forgot a single detail. May she always have a full audience in heaven, and for that last bow, may we all have the courage and the strength she showed us in her final hours.

She is survived by her husband, Carlos; three daughters: Lea (Jeff) Curler, Neenah; Lou Ann (Dave) Reitz, Atlanta, GA; Lori Pennings, Neenah; six grandchildren: Erin Curler, New York, NY; Gina (David) Shurna, Fort Collins, CO; Katie Curler, Appleton; Laura Curler, New Orleans, LA; Christian and Matthew Reitz, both of Atlanta, GA; a great-granddaughter, Clara Shurna.

Carmen was preceded in death by her first husband, Harold, a son, Gary, two sisters: Donna and Carol, and a brother, George.

Funeral services will be held at 7:30 p.m. on Wednesday, January 9, 2008 at Westgor Funeral Home, Neenah, with Fr. Michael Ingold officiating. A visitation will be held from 4:30 until the hour of service on Wednesday at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the American Cancer Society in Carmen's name.

Posted January 9, 2008

Baye Sr., Bernard Joseph

Bernard Joseph Baye, Sr., 87, a lifelong Green Bay area resident, died at his home, Monday, Jan. 7, 2008, surrounded by his loving family. He was born Feb. 13, 1920, the son of Hubert and Philomena (Alsteen) Baye. He was a member of the Saints Peter and Paul 6th, 7th and 8th grade championship teams and held 220-yard dash record in the Fox River Valley Conference from 1938 to 1963. Bernard graduated from Green Bay East High School with the Class of 1938. On May 23, 1942, he married Constance "Connie" Kelley at Saints Peter and Paul Catholic Church. From 1942 to 1945, he served his country with the U.S. Army Engineers 998th Treadway Bridge Company and participated in five campaigns in Europe, including acting as liaison officer between the 1137th Engineer Combat Group and his unit during the Battle of the Bulge in Belgium for which he was commended. His company became famed for building the 1st tactical bridge across the Rhine River at Remagen, Germany. He also served a year as a Staff Sergeant with the National Guard. Bernard was a certified Police Science Instructor at NWTC and a volunteer teacher's aide at Franklin Middle School. He was the first Chief Deputy Sheriff of the Brown County Sheriff's Department, serving in that position for 21 years before retiring in March of 1982, after over 35 years of service. For several years, he coached football and basketball at Saints
